member.name: T:JetBrains.Annotations.InvokerParameterNameAttribute

member.name: T:JetBrains.Annotations.NotifyPropertyChangedInvocatorAttribute
member.summary: Indicates that the method is contained in a type that implements interface and this method is used to notify that some property value changed
member.remarks:
The method should be non-static and conform to one of the supported signatures:
NotifyChanged(string)
NotifyChanged(params string[])
NotifyChanged{T}(Expression{Func{T}})
NotifyChanged{T,U}(Expression{Func{T,U}})
SetProperty{T}(ref T, T, string)

member.name: T:JetBrains.Annotations.ContractAnnotationAttribute
member.summary: Describes dependency between method input and output
member.syntax:
Function Definition Table syntax:
FDT ::= FDTRow [;FDTRow]*
FDTRow ::= Input => Output | Output <= Input
Input ::= ParameterName: Value [, Input]*
Output ::= [ParameterName: Value]* {halt|stop|void|nothing|Value}
Value ::= true | false | null | notnull | canbenull
If method has single input parameter, it's name could be omitted.
Using halt (or void/nothing, which is the same) for method output means that the methos doesn't return normally.
canbenull annotation is only applicable for output parameters.
You can use multiple [ContractAnnotation] for each FDT row, or use single attribute with rows separated by semicolon.

item.code: [ContractAnnotation("halt <= condition: false")] public void Assert(bool condition, string text) // regular assertion method
[ContractAnnotation("s:null => true")] public bool IsNullOrEmpty(string s) // string.IsNullOrEmpty()
[ContractAnnotation("s:null=>false; =>true,result:notnull; =>false, result:null")] public bool TryParse(string s, out Person result)

member.name: T:Thinksquirrel.Fluvio.FluidCollider
member.summary: Represents a three dimensional fluid collider.
member.remarks: Fluid colliders are a special type of fluid that serve as collision boundaries for fluid simulation.

member.name: P:Thinksquirrel.Fluvio.FluidCollider.attatchedCollider
member.summary: The attatched collider. This must be on the same GameObject as the fluid collider.

member.name: P:Thinksquirrel.Fluvio.FluidCollider.fillCollider
member.summary: Controls whether or not the collider should be filled.
member.remarks: Filled colliders provide better simulation for solid objects and higher velocity objects, but have a higher performance overhead (especially in 3D). For edge and terrain colliders, this will always return false.

member.name: P:Thinksquirrel.Fluvio.FluidCollider.wheelColliderThickness
member.summary: Controls the thickness of the collider when using attached wheel colliders.
member.remarks: This has no effect for other collider types.

member.remarks: Fluid colliders are a special type of fluid that serve as collision boundaries for fluid simulation.

member.summary: The attatched collider. This must be on the same GameObject as the fluid collider.

member.summary: Controls whether or not the collider should be filled.
member.remarks: Filled colliders provide better simulation for solid objects and higher velocity objects, but have a higher performance overhead (especially in 3D). For edge and terrain colliders, this will always return false.

member.summary: Controls whether or not collider bounds are calculated automatically.
member.remarks: If set to manual, a set of bounds can be used to voxelize the collider instead. This can be useful to decrease the amount of boundary particles generated.

member.summary: Gets or sets a set of bounds for voxelizing the collider.
member.remarks: These bounds are only used when manual bounds are enabled.

member.summary: Controls whether or not the collider should be filled.
member.remarks: Filled colliders provide better simulation for solid objects and higher velocity objects, but have a higher performance overhead (especially in 3D). For edge and terrain colliders, this will always return false.

member.name: M:Thinksquirrel.Fluvio.FluidColliderBase.ForceColliderUpdate(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Forces the collider to update during the next solver synchronization step.
member.param: If true, update the collider immediately.
member.remarks: In most cases, the collider will update automatically. However, colliders need to be manually updated in some situations. Even when updating immediately, the boundary particles that make up the collider will still only be uploaded during the synchronization step.

member.name: M:Thinksquirrel.Fluvio.FluidColliderBase.Voxelize

member.name: T:Thinksquirrel.Fluvio.FluidEffect
member.summary: Renders a fluid as screen space metaballs.

member.name: P:Thinksquirrel.Fluvio.FluidEffect.depthPassCount
member.summary: The amount of depth passes to render.
member.remarks: Additional depth passes will ensure that overlapping particles will render correctly. However, each depth pass requires the fluid to be rendered again and increases the performance cost.

member.name: P:Thinksquirrel.Fluvio.FluidEffect.depthPassFactor
member.summary: Controls the size of each depth pass.
member.remarks: The final size of a depth pass is the depth pass factor multiplied by the fluid's smoothing distance.

member.name: P:Thinksquirrel.Fluvio.FluidEffect.particleFilterMode
member.summary: The filter mode for the particle render texture.

member.name: P:Thinksquirrel.Fluvio.FluidEffect.additionalRenderers
member.summary: Additional renderers (other than the fluid's renderer) that should be processed by this fluid effect.
member.remarks: Additional renderers should have the same layer and shader as the fluid.

member.name: M:Thinksquirrel.Fluvio.FluidEffect.CompareTo(Thinksquirrel.Fluvio.FluidEffect,UnityEngine.Camera)
member.summary: Compares a fluid effect's rendering order to another.
member.param: The fluid effect to compare.
The optional camera to use for comparison. If no camera is specified, the current or main camera is used, if available.
member.returns: A comparison between the two effects (-1, 0, or 1).
member.remarks: Fluid effects are sorted by sorting layer, sorting fudge, distance, and render queue, in order. Additionally, the effect's renderer and additional renderers are rendered as one batch and sorted by Unity.

member.name: T:Thinksquirrel.Fluvio.FluvioSettings
member.summary: This class controls global Fluvio settings.

member.name: F:Thinksquirrel.Fluvio.FluvioSettings.kComputeThreadGroupSize
member.summary: Compute shader thread group size (single dimension).

member.name: F:Thinksquirrel.Fluvio.FluvioSettings.kComputeThreadGroupSizeX
member.summary: Compute shader thread group size (X).

member.name: F:Thinksquirrel.Fluvio.FluvioSettings.kComputeThreadGroupSizeY
member.summary: Compute shader thread group size (Y).

member.name: F:Thinksquirrel.Fluvio.FluvioSettings.kComputeThreadGroupSizeZ
member.summary: Compute shader thread group size (Z).

member.name: F:Thinksquirrel.Fluvio.FluvioSettings.kEpsilon
member.summary: Minimum float value for fluid simulation.

member.name: F:Thinksquirrel.Fluvio.FluvioSettings.kMaxSqrVelocityChange
member.summary: Maximum squared velocity magnitude that will be applied in a single solver iteration. Higher values are ignored. Prevents numerical errors.

member.name: F:Thinksquirrel.Fluvio.FluvioSettings.kTurbulenceConstant
member.summary: Turbulence constant for vortical forces.

member.name: F:Thinksquirrel.Fluvio.FluvioSettings.kMaxPluginBuffers
member.summary: Maximum amount of plugin buffers supported.
member.remarks: Plugin values also take up buffer spots. The actual amount of plugin buffers that can be used is platform-dependent. For mobile platforms, it is recommended to not have more than two plugin buffers (or one read-write plugin buffer). It is highly recommended to pack plguin information into structs in order to use as few buffers as possible.

member.name: F:Thinksquirrel.Fluvio.FluvioSettings.kFluidColliderSkinWidth
member.summary: Fluid collider skin width. This is multiplied by the fluid's smoothing distance to determine boundary skin width.

member.name: F:Thinksquirrel.Fluvio.FluvioSettings.kFluidColliderMaxParticleCount
member.summary: Fluid colldier maximum particle count.

member.name: P:Thinksquirrel.Fluvio.FluvioSettings.preloadComputeShaders
member.summary: Preload compute shaders whenever possible.
member.remarks: This currently only applies to OpenCL and can only be changed in the editor. All OpenCL shaders will preload with the first API call to any Fluvio object, even if a fluid is not yet in the scene. Shaders will not preload in edit mode.

member.name: P:Thinksquirrel.Fluvio.FluvioSettings.fixedDeltaTime
member.summary: Controls the default physics time step for fluid simulation.

member.name: P:Thinksquirrel.Fluvio.FluvioSettings.maxDeltaTime
member.summary: Controls the maximum physics time step for fluid simulation.

member.name: P:Thinksquirrel.Fluvio.FluvioSettings.limitTimestep
member.summary: If true, limits the frame timestep based on real time passed.
member.remarks: This helps prevent runaway physics, in the cases where the amount of computational time to simulate a timestep is longer than the amount of time passed. It is recommended to leave this on for realtime use.

member.name: P:Thinksquirrel.Fluvio.FluvioSettings.solverIterations
member.summary: Controls the amount of solver iterations.

member.name: P:Thinksquirrel.Fluvio.FluvioSettings.motionExtrapolation
member.summary: Enables or disables motion extrapolation.
member.remarks: Motion extrapolation extrapolates the position of particles between physics frames for a smoother experience and a lower overall computational cost. It is recommended to keep this enabled, especially for VR.

member.name: P:Thinksquirrel.Fluvio.FluvioSettings.useIndexGrid
member.summary: Whether or not an index grid should be used to accelerate neighbor search.
member.remarks: In almost all situations, this should be enabled. The index grid significantly accelerates particle simulation, in exchange for an additional memory cost. Changing this value will trigger a recompile of all compute shaders and can only be changed in the editor.

member.name: P:Thinksquirrel.Fluvio.FluvioSettings.maxGridSize
member.summary: The maximum amount of grid cells to have in any one direction (X/Y or X/Y/Z). Cells are the same size as the root fluid's smoothing distance.
member.remarks: Grid sizes have a very large affect on fluid memory usage and performance. It is recommended to use the default values in almost every case. Changing this value will trigger a recompile of all compute shaders and can only be changed in the editor.

member.name: P:Thinksquirrel.Fluvio.FluvioSettings.gridBucketSize
member.summary: The maximum amount of particles per grid cell.
member.remarks: Grid sizes have a very large affect on fluid memory usage and performance. It is recommended to use the default values in almost every case. Changing this value will trigger a recompile of all compute shaders and can only be changed in the editor.

member.name: P:Thinksquirrel.Fluvio.FluvioSettings.gridBytes
member.summary: Gets the size of the index grid, in bytes.
member.remarks: This can be used to evaluate whether or not the target device has enough memory to support the index grid. If the index grid is disabled, returns 0.

member.name: P:Thinksquirrel.Fluvio.FluvioSettings.particleStride2D
member.summary: Particle stride for solver arrays for 2D fluids. Equal to 9 full grid cells minus one particle (gridBucketSize * 9 - 1).

member.name: P:Thinksquirrel.Fluvio.FluvioSettings.particleStride3D
member.summary: Particle stride for solver arrays for 3D fluids. Equal to 27 full grid cells minus one particle (gridBucketSize * 27 - 1).

member.name: P:Thinksquirrel.Fluvio.FluvioSettings.desiredThreads
member.summary: The desired amount of threads to use globally for fluid simulation and other parallel tasks.
member.remarks: The maximum amount of threads used (including the main thread) will always be the amount of logical cores in the system. Setting the desired amount of threads can greatly affect performance. When setting this property, the current thread will wait on all running tasks to complete. If the current platform does not support multithreading, this will have no effect.

member.name: P:Thinksquirrel.Fluvio.FluvioSettings.currentThreadCount
member.summary: The current amount of threads used for fluid simulation and other parallel tasks.
member.remarks: The maximum amount of threads used will always be the amount of logical cores in the system - 1. If the current platform does not support multithreading, this will return a value of 1.

member.name: P:Thinksquirrel.Fluvio.FluvioSettings.threadPriority
member.summary: Controls the thread priority for fluid simulation and other parallel tasks.

member.name: P:Thinksquirrel.Fluvio.FluvioSettings.desiredComputeAPI
member.summary: Controls the desired compute API for hardware accelerated fluid simulation.

member.name: P:Thinksquirrel.Fluvio.FluvioSettings.openCLDesiredDeviceType
member.summary: Controls the desired device type when using OpenCL hardware acceleration.
member.remarks: Using a CPU device may perform better for applications that are GPU bound, or for GPUs that have a low CPU/GPU memory latency or poor compute capabilities. Using a GPU device may perform better for applications that are CPU bound when using larger particle counts on a system with low CPU/GPU memory latency. When multiple devices of the same class exist, these devices are given a score based on the number of compute cores and processor speed, and the device with the highest score is picked. Blacklisted devices are always skipped, regardless of their type.

member.name: P:Thinksquirrel.Fluvio.FluvioSettings.enableOpenCLGPUOnOSX
member.summary: Controls whether or not OpenCL GPU and accelerator devices are enabled on Mac OS X. This feature is experimental, and off by default.
member.remarks: Due to driver issues, some Mac OS devices may crash with OpenCL in GPU mode. This option allows for a global override on whether or not GPU devices should be considered for simulation on Mac OS X devices.

member.name: P:Thinksquirrel.Fluvio.FluvioSettings.openCLDeviceBlacklist
member.summary: Controls device strings that should be blacklisted when using OpenCL.
member.remarks: When changing these values, accelerated fluids must have their buffers reinitialized using ReinitializeAllAcceleratedFluids manually.

member.name: P:Thinksquirrel.Fluvio.FluvioSettings.openCLPlatformBlacklist
member.summary: Controls platforms that should be blacklisted when using OpenCL.
member.remarks: When changing these values, accelerated fluids must have their buffers reinitialized using ReinitializeAllAcceleratedFluids manually.

member.name: P:Thinksquirrel.Fluvio.FluvioSettings.enableTimers
member.summary: Enables or disables timers. This should be disabled for release builds.
member.remarks: The FluidDebug plugin enables this by default.

member.name: M:Thinksquirrel.Fluvio.FluvioSettings.GetCurrentComputeAPI
member.summary: Gets the current compute API used for Fluvio.
member.returns: The desired compute API, or a fallback if available.

member.name: M:Thinksquirrel.Fluvio.FluvioSettings.ForceInitializeOpenCL(Cloo.ComputeDevice)
member.summary: Force an initialization of OpenCL.
member.param: An optional compute device to use (from the Cloo OpenCL library). This can be used to force a specific OpenCL device, overriding the detault device option.
member.remarks: This should only be called if OpenCL has already been initialized and the desired device type, platform blacklist, or device blacklist have changed.

member.name: M:Thinksquirrel.Fluvio.FluvioSettings.ReinitializeAllAcceleratedFluids
member.summary: Reinitialize all accelerated fluids in the scene.
member.remarks: This will not reset simulation, but is a very performance-intensive operation.

member.summary: Get the name of the current compute platform for the specified fluid.
member.param: The fluid to get the compute platform name for.
member.returns: The name and version of the current compute platform.

member.summary: Get the name of the current compute device for the specified fluid.
member.param: The fluid to get the compute device name for.
member.returns: The name of the current compute device.

member.name: T:Thinksquirrel.Fluvio.Plugins.FluidParticlePairPlugin
member.summary: Base class for all fluid plugins that operate on particle pairs.

member.name: M:Thinksquirrel.Fluvio.Plugins.FluidParticlePairPlugin.OnUpdatePlugin(Thinksquirrel.Fluvio.Plugins.SolverData,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Provides an update method for the fluid plugin. If the fluid and plugin are hardware accelerated, this method will not be executed.
member.param: Solver data for the current simulation. This can be used to modify forces and other physical parameters.
The current particle index for the update.
The current neighbor index for the update.
member.remarks: This method provides internal solver data, along with the indices of a particle and its neighbor. Because this method may run on multiple threads along with other plugins, the neighbor particle should NOT be modified. Each pair will execute twice (A -> B and B -> A). Also note that neighbor information may not be up to date (it may be modified on another thread at any time). It is recommended to access each neighbor property only once, in order to keep physical consistency and reduce potential numerical errors.

The current particle index for the update.
member.remarks: This method provides internal solver data, along with the index of a particle. This method may run on multiple threads - arrays should be modified only at the particle index.

member.name: M:Thinksquirrel.Fluvio.Plugins.FluidPlugin.Awake
member.summary: This is called by Unity when the plugin is enabled for the first time. Overriding classes MUST call base.Awake() to initialize the plugin properly.
member.remarks: Plugins should use OnEnablePlugin or OnResetPlugin instead.

member.name: M:Thinksquirrel.Fluvio.Plugins.FluidPlugin.Reset
member.summary: This is called by Unity when the plugin is reset, or by Fluvio when the plugin is created for the first time. Overriding classes MUST call base.Reset() to initialize the plugin properly.
member.remarks: Plugins should use OnResetPlugin instead.
